direction.raw_text: . COFFEE BAR. DAY                                       13 Jenny and two school friends, HATTIE and TINA, are sitting at a table in a typical late-50s coffee bar, sipping cappuccinos. Jenny is easily the most attractive of the three - and also, we will see, possibly the cleverest. HATTIE is slower than the other two, and a lot frumpier; TINA is pretty, and sharp rather than clever. She is also the least middle-class of the three - she's clearly a scholarship girl. They are all dressed in an unflattering and unambiguous school uniform - no attempts to disguise it with more fashionable accessories. Jenny is smoking pretentiously, and seems to be practising some kind of pout. Tina starts to slurp the froth from her cappuccino with a spoon, inelegantly and noisily. Jenny tuts her disapproval. Tina sighs, and puts her spoon down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The whole point about him is that he doesn't feel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We still don't have to like him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Camus doesn't want you to like him. What he's trying to say is that feeling is bourgeois. Being engagee is bourgeois. His mother dies and he doesn't feel anything. He kills this Arab and he doesn't feel anything.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wouldn't feel anything if my mother died. Does that make me an existentialist?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. That just makes you a cow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Une vache. Laughter. 14   EXT. STREET/COFFEE BAR. DAY                                   14 Jenny, Hattie and Tina emerge from the cafe, talking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well I'm going to be French. I'm going to Paris and I'm going to smoke and listen to Jacques Brel and wear black. And I won't speak. Ever. C'est plus chic, comme... She breaks off. Parked outside a tobacconists on the other side of the road is the red Bristol. She looks towards the shop, and David emerges with a copy of the Times and a packet of cigars. Jenny crosses the road to talk to him while the others watch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello. Thank you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How did it go?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, fine. I think. I mean, I didn't mess my bit up, anyway. And no-one got thrown out of the orchestra afterwards.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Always the mark of a cultural triumph. Listen. I'm glad I ran into you. What are you doing on Friday?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Going to school.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I meant the evening.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh. Yes. Of course. Nothing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because I'm going to listen to some Schubert in St John's, Smith Square. My friends Danny and Helen will be going too, so it wouldn't be...I'll tell you what. I'll come and pick you up, and if your mother and father disapprove, then you can have the tickets and go with one of them. How does that sound? Jenny doesn't know what to say. She looks at David, and his eagerness to please seems to convince her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you. And I'd like you to take me. I'd like to go with someone who knows when to clap.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I usually watch Danny. He knows that sort of thing. Jenny smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Seven? And we'll probably go for a spot of supper afterwards, if you...But if you, if that's not...Well, we can always put you in a taxi.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (flat disbelief) Supper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you want.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The trouble is, we'll already have eaten.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well. I mean, if you'd like supper, then, perhaps on Friday you could...not eat?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (embarrassed again) Oh. Yes. Of course. Jenny smiles, and rejoins her friends on the other side of the road. Tina and Hattie are standing there almost with their mouths open, amazed. She doesn't say anything and starts to walk on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry. I just had the strangest dream. I dreamed you crossed the road and spoke to a handsome man with the most beautiful car I've ever seen. And then you came back and you didn't mention it. Jenny smiles enigmatically. Tina grabs Jenny mock-urgently.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: `Oo wazzee?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (light, playful) Just a man who's been trying to pick me up. We're going to a concert on Friday night. And then we're having a spot of supper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (shrieking) A spot of supper?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You've heard of supper?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We've heard of it. But we've never eaten it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Neither of you is interested in the concert part, I notice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. Of course not.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh my God! I've only just realised! That's what's going to happen to you, isn't it? Look at her! Men are going to pick her up in the street and take her out to supper!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: God, you're right, Tina. I hadn't thought of that. Look at her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't be so daft.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're trying to attract the attention of boys.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . And she's fighting off men. Anyway. You're going to have to tell us more than that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because no man's ever   going to ask us out to supper.   Not until we're ladies, anyway.   You're going to have to tell   us everything. Otherwise   it's not fair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There won't be anything to tell.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, make something up, then. 15   INT. JENNY'S HOUSE. EVENING                                  15 Jenny is dressed up for her evening out. She looks good, but also stiff, uncomfortable - she's not herself in her dress, which looks too old for her. Her father is standing in front of her, shouting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I won't allow it!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (coolly) Fine. He's quite happy for you to take me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (uncertainly) Right. I will.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where is it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: St John's Smith Square.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where's that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know. I'm sure we could find out. Marjorie comes into the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's in Westminster. Just around the corner from the Abbey. Jack looks at her as if she'd just given directions to the nearest opium den.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How d'you know that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I had a life before we were married, you know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He soon put a stop to that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There we are.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where are we?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The trouble is, that's where St John's Smith Square is.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And I've just said. That's where I'm not going. There must be something on locally. Where's the paper?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jack, she wants to see someone who can play. She doesn't want to see Sheila Kirkland scratching away. I'll take her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And how are you going to get over there? RAF helicopter? The doorbell rings.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's him. Now what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, bloody hell.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jack!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Jenny starts towards the door, and then turns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, and by the way...David's a Jew. A wandering Jew. So watch yourself. She   goes to the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (panic-stricken and shouting) What's she talking about? I've never said anything like that in my life! Anyway, it's just an expression! I'm not against the Jews! Jenny comes back in with David, who is dressed stylishly in his early-60s young executive leisurewear - sports jacket, slacks, cashmere sweater. He looks out of place - he is brighter and brasher than his surroundings, the most colourful thing in the room, and he seems intimidatingly exotic. David has obviously heard Jack's last line.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (pleasantly) I'm glad to hear it. Hello. David Goldman. He offers his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I didn't mean I'm not against you... Actually, I did mean that, because I'm not, but...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dad! David's hand is still extended - in his confusion and embarrassment, Jack hasn't yet taken it. He does so now, and shakes it for way too long.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry. What I'm saying is that you're not the sort of, of person I'd be against, if I were the sort of person who was against...people. You're not an old...Oh, dear. I'm Jack, and this is Marjorie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (deadpan) You didn't tell me you had a sister, Jenny. General confusion, until David chuckles naughtily. Marjorie giggles, and then offers her hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're a lucky man, Jack.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I suppose I am, yes. They all sit down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So. Gosh. (He looks around approvingly.) This is lovely. Marjorie smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry, David. Can I get you a drink?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'd love one, Jack, but we're running a little late. If Jenny's ready, perhaps we'll shoot off. Jenny looks at her father, and takes a calculated gamble.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ah. Well. Dad's got something to tell you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, no, nothing...It was more of a question, really. How would you get to St John's Smith Square from here? For future reference?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, it's a pretty straight run, really. Up to Hammersmith, take the A4 through Kensington and you're there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simple as that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simple as that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Jack smiles broadly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (playfully) So shall I book some tickets for something?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (still smiling) No. Beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Back by ten, please, David. She's usually in bed by then. Jenny winces.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was hoping Jenny would come with me afterwards to have a bite of supper with my aunt Helen. Jenny studies him carefully. Suddenly his friends Danny and Helen have become `Aunt Helen'.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, well, I suppose...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How about if I promise to have her in by eleven thirty?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, it's Friday night. And if you're going out to the West End...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thanks, Jack. I appreciate it. See you again. They exchange warm handshakes. He turns to Marjorie. Marjorie extends her hand. David takes it, but kisses it suavely,leaving her a little flustered.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Have a nice time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bye. Jenny and David leave.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's that smell? Has he got perfume on?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's called after-shave, Jack. And it makes a change from carbolic soap.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At least there's no confusion, if you smell of carbolic soap. Marjorie rolls her eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nobody's ever going to get confused about you, dear. 15A   EXT. ST JOHN'S, SMITH SQUARE. NIGHT                        15A Jenny and David walk toward the beautiful hall. Jenny suddenly looks young in the dress that looks too old for her - other adults are milling around outside, and the women don't look like girls dressed up. David makes for an incredibly glamorous and attractive couple in their late twenties who are waiting outside - DANNY and HELEN. Helen is as far from anyone's idea of an aunt as one can get. She's no more beautiful than Jenny, but she's dressed both appropriately and spectacularly, in early-60s, pre-hippy Bohemian gear. She turns heads in a way that Jenny is not yet able to. Danny too is attractive, but soberly so. David and Jenny are, in a way, paler, less striking versions of these two.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello hello. Are we late?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: fascinated and clearly appraising looks. They have heard about her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shall we? They walk into the hall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: surroundings and the company. She's particularly bowled over by Helen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look. We can leave our coats over there. I want to get rid of this. She nods at the coat she's carrying. Jenny looks thrilled at the prospect of spending a couple of minutes with Helen. Danny hands Helen his coat, without saying anything. The girls walk over to another reception table a few yards away, behind which is a cloakroom. A lady is exchanging overcoats for tickets. Almost involuntarily, Jenny touches the sleeve of Helen's velvety jacket. She stops herself. Helen notices.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm so sorry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (amused) That's OK. It's nice, isn't it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's beautiful. Where did it come from?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, South Ken somewhere. Helen looks at Jenny's outfit, her frumpy `smart' dress, apparently wanting to return the compliment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (nodding at the dress) This is...Well, it's good for this sort of concert, isn't it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (quietly) Thank you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Helen is now at the front of the queue, and hands her coat over imperiously.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We should go shopping together one day, if you want. She takes a ticket from the cloakroom lady.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That would be nice. But South Ken... C'est beaucoup trop cher pour moi. They stare at each other. Helen is bewildered, Jenny embarrassed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sorry?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I just said....It was too expensive for me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No you didn't. You said something completely different.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I just...Well, I said it in French.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In French? Why? Jenny feels humiliated; she is yet to realise what we can see - that Helen is simply very dim.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know. Jenny looks away. Helen stares at her. The performance bell rings, and they make their way back to the men. To Jenny's surprise and pleasure, Helen links arms with her as they walk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anyway. It's too expensive for me, too. We don't have to worry about that. If you want something in South Ken, get David to take you shopping.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why on earth would he want to take me shopping?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Helen makes a knowing face. 17   INT. ST JOHN'S SMITH SQUARE. NIGHT                           17 David, Jenny, Danny and Helen in a row in the middle of the auditorium, watching the stage and listening to the music. Jenny can't concentrate - she's too excited by the occasion and the company. Jenny sneaks a glance at Helen, who stares straight ahead, unblinking and enigmatic. David is smiling, as if he's trying to communicate enjoyment; Danny's eyes flicker across the stage - he understands the music, its component parts, which musicians are contributing what. Jenny takes it all in. 18   EXT. ST JOHN'S SMITH SQUARE. NIGHT                           18 Jenny, David, Danny and Helen emerge with the other concert- goers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I booked a table at Juliette's. Will that kill the mood, do you think?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, I do hope so. The others laugh.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I always think I'm going to my own funeral when I listen to classical music. (Tentatively) That was classical, wasn't it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. Very classical. As classical as you can get. Helen looks pleased.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Juliette's it is, then. Heaven forbid that we should end the evening reflecting on our own mortality. Jenny smiles in delight. She's never met people like this. 19   INT. JULIETTE'S. NIGHT                                       19 A singer in the Julie London mould is singing `I'm In The Mood For Love' while cigarette girls and glamorous waitresses patrol the tables.

direction.raw_text: . Jenny is sitting with the others at a table in the club, eating and talking. She looks about twelve, but she's thrilled to be there. We know now that her life can never be the same again, and there will be no going back to fish- paste sandwiches with spotty Graham.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Francoise Sagan"? Jenny shakes her head. Her eyes are wide - she's clearly awe-struck. David offers her a cigarette - a Gitane - which she takes. He lights it for her while she's listening.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, it's wonderful.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've only got....Well, I think it's just called `Juliette Greco'. The one with the eyes on the sleeve. I saved up and got my French conversation teacher to bring it back after Christmas.

direction.raw_text: You've got a French conversation teacher?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is that why you suddenly speak French for no reason?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You must have seen her sing? Jenny shakes her head again and smiles. Where would she have seen Juliette Greco? Danny, meanwhile, is baffled. Who hasn't seen Juliette Greco?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's marvellous.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But you should see her in Paris, not here. David will take you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'd love to. You'd fit right in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (sympathetically) Better than here, really.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's wonderful to find a young person who wants to know things. There's so much I want you to see. They sip their drinks pensively, possibly to allow time for the double-entendre to disappear into the smoke.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you still all right to come and have a look at that Pembroke Villas place with me on Friday, Danny?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh. No. Can't do it. There's a Burne-Jones coming up at Christie's on Friday. And I want it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (laughing in disbelief) You're thinking of buying a Burne- Jones? A real one?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I just have a feeling that the pre-Raphaelites are going to take off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I love the pre-Raphaelites.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (excited by her education) Do you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, of course. Rossetti and Burne-Jones, anyway. Not Holman Hunt, so much. He's so garish. Danny looks at her. There's clearly more to this schoolgirl than he thought.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Absolutely! Why don't we all go to the auction? Wouldn't that be fun?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: An auction. Gosh. How exciting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Next Friday morning. David will pick you up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (crestfallen) Oh. Friday.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're busy?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well. Yes. She doesn't want to explain why.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: French?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you sure you're busy? Jenny hesitates.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. I'm sure I could....re- arrange. That would be lovely. 20   INT. JENNY'S HOUSE. NIGHT                                   20 Jenny lets herself quietly into the house. The hallway is dark, but she can hear noises from the kitchen. She pokes her head round the corner, and sees her mother doing the washing-up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, hello, love. Did you have a nice time?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are you doing?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't get this casserole dish clean. We had hot-pot tonight, and it's all burnt round...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's twenty-five to twelve. We finish tea at seven.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know what the time is. How was your evening?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It was...It was the best night of my life.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And he took you home in his car? Right to the door? Jenny looks at her. She doesn't seem to have heard what Jenny has just said.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Goodnight, Mum.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And I'm glad you enjoyed the concert. 21   INT. CLASSROOM. DAY                                             21 Jenny, Hattie and Tina are    sitting on their desks, waiting for the start of a lesson.    Nine or ten classmates are scattered around the room,    talking distractedly, but Jenny's group is much more    animated: Tina and Hattie are leaning forward, listening    to Jenny, their eyes bright. They are clearly awestruck    by Jenny's tales of the outside world.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not interested in Schubert. I want to know what else was on the programme. Laughter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There was nothing like that. He was the perfect gentleman. He just said he wanted to take me places and show me things.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Things plural? Oh my Gawd! More laughter. The English teacher, MISS STUBBS, young and fresh-faced and lively-looking, enters, and picks up on the excitement of Jenny's coterie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I knew that in the end `Jane Eyre' would work its magic upon you. I'm presuming that's what you're so animated about. The students start to sit down at desks in a more conventional arrangement.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: `Jane Eyre' and Jenny's new boyfriend.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's not my "new boyfriend". God.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's true. He's more a man- friend, isn't he? He's got a sports-car, Miss Stubbs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ah. A Mr Rochester figure.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think he must be as blind as Mr Rochester. Laughter. Jenny pulls a face at her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is there no end to your thirst for literary understanding, Jenny? As you may have noticed, I'm attempting to turn the subject away from Jenny's lurid love-life and towards the matter in hand. She starts to hand out essays.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And it's quite clear on this evidence that most of you know much too much about the former, and almost nothing about the latter. Reluctantly I must concede that Jenny is evidently an expert on both matters. Excellent as always, Jenny. Miss Stubbs slaps an essay down on Jenny's desk. We can see that it's marked `A+'.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 22   INT. JENNY'S BEDROOM. NIGHT                                  22 Jenny at her desk, working. She puts down her pen, distracted. 23   INT. DAVID'S CAR. DAY                                        23 David sitting in his Bristol, waiting. 24   EXT. SCHOOL. DAY                                             24 We see the Bristol parked outside, and Jenny walking towards it, a small figure in a large playground. She's clearly just changed out of her school uniform, and she's making last-minute adjustments to her civvies. A teacher walks towards her, and Jenny almost freezes - but the teacher merely smiles pleasantly and walks past. Jenny keeps walking at a measured pace for a moment and then breaks into a run. 25   INT/EXT. CAR/DILAPIDATED HOUSE. DAY                          25 Jenny and David are driving along a North Kensington street.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How do you know Danny? David is distracted. He's driving slowly, apparently looking for an address.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, you know. We kept bumping into each other, and we became pals, and we've ended up doing a bit of work together, when it suits us.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What kind of work?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Property. A bit of art dealing. Some buying and selling. This and that... He stops the car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll be two seconds. He gets out of the car, and Jenny watches him as he crosses the road.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Outside a dilapidated house covered in scaffolding stands a large West Indian family, mother, father, three or four small children and a dog. They are surrounded by what appears to be all their worldly goods. David squats down on his haunches, talks to the kids, tousles the hair of the smallest. Then he takes out a bunch of keys and ushers the family down the path. He unlocks the door and leads them inside. In an upper window of the house, we see an old lady peering down anxiously. 26   EXT. STREET/DILAPIDATED HOUSE. DAY                           26 David emerges from the house, jangling his keys. 27   INT. CAR. DAY                                                27 Jenny opens the glove compartment where David keeps his cigarettes, takes out the packet, removes one for herself, offers the packet to David as he gets into the car. He lights them both.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry about that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How do you know those, those ...Negro people?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They're clients.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clients?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jenny darling, even schwarzers have to live somewhere. And it's not as if they can rent off their own kind, is it? He starts the car and drives off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not sure I quite understand what you do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You don't need to. It's too boring. All you need to know is that I work in property so that I can take you to nice places. Jenny's POV of the black family in one window, and the little old lady disappearing from another.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 28   INT. CHRISTIE'S. DAY                                           28 Danny intent on a catalogue, Helen gazing dreamily into space, as David and Jenny push their way through the crowded auction room. The auctioneer burbles on in the background.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You nearly missed it. Jenny is in awe of rich London in all its finery. The auctioneer clears his throat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We turn to lot 41, The Tree of Forgiveness, by Sir Edward Burne- Jones. This is a rare opportunity to purchase a key work of the Pre- Raphaelite movement. Who will start me off at five hundred guineas? Jenny glances at Danny. He makes no move at this price. Neither does anyone else. He's poised and listening hard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Two hundred? A middle-aged lady, the epitome of the middle-aged contemporary Sloane, twin-set, pearls and a lot of      face powder, raises her hand.
direction.name: direction

It shouldn't spend its life on a wall in wherever the hell we are. It should be with us. We know how to look after it properly. We liberated it. Jenny snorts derisively.

You drink everything I put in front of you down in one, every last drop, and then you slam your glass down on the bar and ask for more, and it's wonderful. We're not clever like you, so we have to be clever in other ways, because if we weren't, there would be no fun.

direction.raw_text: . We have to be clever with maps, and..and.. You want to know what stats are? Stats are old ladies who are scared of coloured people. So I move the coloureds in and the old ladies move out and I buy their flats cheap. That's what I do. So now you know. Jenny nods reluctantly.

direction.raw_text: So, please...No Minnies. No baby- talk. I'm not old enough for baby- talk. Treat me like a grown-up. David looks chastened.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (brightly) I know. Let's go and sit in our sitting-room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (cheered up) Hooray! I'll order some champagne. Jenny looks at him with what might, from one angle, be construed as fondness. MONTAGE SEQUENCE - PARIS 64   EXT. LEFT BANK. DAY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 66   INT. RECORD SHOP. DAY                                        66 We see three listening booths, all containing customers. Jenny and David are in the middle booth, listening to the Juliette Greco song on the soundtrack. (For a moment, the sound quality changes - soundtrack becomes source music, seamlessly.) Jenny is studying the sleeve. She wants to hug herself, she's so excited. 67   EXT. CAFE. EVENING.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you still feel like a schoolgirl? Jenny turns round, smiles, shakes her head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And it wasn't too uncomfortable?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not after the...first bit. It's funny, though, isn't it? All that poetry, and all those songs and films, about something that lasts no time at all? David looks at her. She isn't being cruel. She just doesn't know any different. She returns to her people-watching. He smokes ruminatively.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 71   EXT. PARK. DAY                                             71 ...Jenny in her games kit, smoking her Sobranie with her friends on the park bench again. Hattie and Tina are examining their bottles of Chanel reverently. Jenny is back to being her seventeen-year-old self; somehow her seventeen- year-old self looks comical, and no longer appropriate.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How can you go back to double French when you've had a weekend with an older man in a posh hotel in Paris? You wouldn't catch me coming anywhere near this dump.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (artfully) It wasn't all glamour. We spent half the weekend at Heathrow in a hotel suite .
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A suite? Oh my God. Your life. They smoke their Sobranies ruminatively.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're going to miss it. All the swanning around in posh hotels.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why will I need to miss it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When you go to Oxford. Unless you're planning on being with David forever. Jenny doesn't say anything.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're not, are you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (distracted) God, no.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So? Won't you miss it? Jenny shrugs. Clearly she will, and clearly she hasn't thought about it before.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We'll miss it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Jenny laughs. 72   INT.   CLASSROOM. DAY                                      72 Jenny's English class file past Miss Stubbs at the end of a lesson. Miss Stubbs stops Jenny.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jenny, could I have a word?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course.(To Hattie and Tina) I'll catch you up. Miss Stubbs waits until the room empties.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You can do anything you want, Jenny. You know that. You're clever and you're pretty... But sometimes those things fight. I'm worried that at the moment clever Jenny and pretty Jenny are fighting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you mean?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I couldn't bear it if clever Jenny lost. It's because of people like you that I plough through illiterate essays by Sandra Lovell about her pony. And there aren't many of you, I can tell you. One every few years. Is your boyfriend interested in clever Jenny?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think so.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Interested enough to let her do what she wants?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He couldn't stop me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He might not have to stop you. That's what I'm trying to tell you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (frustrated) I'm not sure what you're trying to tell me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm telling you to go to Oxford. No matter what. Or you'll break my heart. Jenny looks at her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (quietly) Where did you go?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sorry?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (louder, bolder) Where did you go? Which university?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Girton. Cambridge.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What does that mean? `Oh'?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're clever. And you're pretty. So presumably, Clever Miss Stubbs won. And here you are, reading all those pony essays. I don't know. These last few months, I've been to Paris, and to jazz clubs, and I've eaten in wonderful restaurants, and seen wonderful films, heard beautiful music...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sure you have. But I was filled up with beautiful things, books and music and conversation, in exactly the same way at Cambridge. And I didn't have to pay the same sort of price. Are you taking precautions, Jenny? Jenny stares at her angrily.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's nothing to do with that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Isn't it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe our lives are always going to end up with pony essays. Or housework. And yes, maybe we'll go up to Oxford. But if we're all going to die the moment we graduate, maybe it's what we do before that counts.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry you think I'm dead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't think you're dead. But...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (coldly) You'd better get to your next class. She turns her back on Jenny. 73   EXT. CAR. NIGHT                                             73 Helen, Danny, Jenny get out of David's Bristol, which is parked outside a nightclub called Esmerelda's Barn. David has parked next to a white Rolls-Royce.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (looking at the Rolls- Royce) And we know the person who owns this?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. Perec Rachman. He's a....
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A bastard. Danny and David laugh.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's a business acquaintance, and we need to talk to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I gathered that much. But why do we have to crawl around the West End looking for his car? Why don't you just make an appointment, if you want to see him?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . The men snigger.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What? Ring his office? Talk to his secretary? That isn't how it works with him, dear. 74   INT. CLUB. NIGHT                                           74 The four walk in and take their coats over to the cloakroom. The club is a smoky West End club, full of smartly-dressed and dubious-looking men, and young, glamorous, dubious-looking women. Jenny and Helen look out of place - Helen too ethereal, Jenny too innocent. There is jazz playing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There he is. We see a nasty-looking man in his late 30s/early 40s. He is wearing a white sharksin suit and smoking a big cigar. He's standing by the roulette table, talking to an even nastier- looking man in a dark suit. They find a table at the back and sit down. A waitress comes over to their table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A bottle of champagne, please.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh-ho. Champagne, eh? He looks at Jenny and David expectantly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't be bashful.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. Be Sneezy. Everyone ignores her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All right, then. If you won't tell them I will. Jenny got two As and a B in her mock-A levels.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fantastic.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Congratulations.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The B was in Latin. But it's much better than it was, isn't it, Minnie? Rachman is now standing on his own. Danny nudges David, and they go over to talk to him just as the champagne arrives. The waiter pops the bottle of champagne and pours two glasses. The girls smile and clink glasses.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't worry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: About what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Someone told me that in fifty years no-one will speak Latin, probably. Not even Latin people. So you shouldn't mind too much about your B. Jenny stares at her, trying to think of a response. 75   INT. CLUB. NIGHT                                            75 Danny and David are at the bar, having just finished talking to Rachman. Danny puffs out his cheeks and shakes his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I'm not sure you'd want him to marry your sister. I'm not even sure you'd want to talk to him in a night-club, come to that. They both chuckle. There is a silence for a moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (gently) You do know what you're doing, old chap? With Jenny?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is the one, Danny.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We've heard that before.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You can see she's different. She's got everything. You've got Helen, and....
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (drily) And you've got Helen with brains.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't want to see her hurt. They make their way back to their table. 76   INT. CLUB. NIGHT                                            76 While David and Helen watch, Danny and Jenny dance. Danny's a good dancer; Jenny is nervous at first, but becomes more comfortable and more expressive, with Danny's help.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (knowing that she should make conversation, as all the couples around her are doing) Have you...Have you bought any more paintings recently?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Have I? Let's think? Oh, I picked up a little Piper the other day. A good `un, I think.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm still trying to work out what makes good things good. It's hard, isn't it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The thing is, Jenny, you know, without necessarily being able to explain why. You've got taste. That's not even half the battle. That's the whole war. Jenny smiles at him with gratitude. There is a sudden closeness between them. David is watching them carefully. They return to their table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jenny, we should go. It's late.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (disappointed) Oh. Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Alas. One day, school will be over forever, and we can talk about art all night.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to Danny) You're all right in a taxi, aren't you? He guides Jenny firmly out of the club. 77   EXT. CLUB. NIGHT.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wait there. He runs to the back of the car, opens the boot and starts rummaging through it. It seems to be full of everything but the thing he's looking for.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are you doing? He slams the boot shut and comes back empty-handed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will you marry me? Jenny stares at him for a moment, then laughs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What were you looking for?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I thought I had a ring. It wouldn't have been the right one. But it would have done for tonight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (eyes twinkling with amusement) Oh, David.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm serious.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're very sweet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you think?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (helplessly) Please take me home. She gets into the car. We see the desperation in David's face, lit by the headlights of a passing taxi, as he slams the door on Jenny after she's got in. 78   EXT. SCHOOL YARD. DAY                                        78 Jenny, Tina and Hattie all smoking in the school toilets. Jenny is distracted, and standing apart from the others. Tina looks at her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How do you say `A penny for your thoughts?' in French?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A franc is too much, isn't it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For her thoughts, yes. You'd be overpaying by about ninety-nine centimes. Suddenly the door bursts open and the Latin teacher comes in. 79   INT. HEAD'S OFFICE. DAY                                      79 The three girls are lined up in front of the headmistress, hands by their sides.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm surprised that you two are standing in front of me. I'm not surprised to find you here, Miss Mellor, though I do feel rather like the judge who sent Al Capone to prison for tax evasion. We take a very dim view of smoking. We take an even dimmer view of some of your other behaviour, which as far as we know has taken place off school premises. Your appearance here today, however, allows me to remind you that we are trying to teach you how to become young ladies, not nightclub hostesses. In reality, of course, you are neither. You are merely silly little girls. Detention after school. Go away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Jenny's face sets hard. Something in her shuts down. 80    EXT. JENNY'S BALCONY. EVENING                                80 Jenny is smoking on the balcony.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: she can't concentrate. Her hair is tied back in a pony- tail. She gets up, pulls back the curtains, looks out of the window. We see what she sees: a sleepy suburban street at night. She looks back at her desk. It looks even more boring than the street. She looks at her scrubbed seventeen- year-old face in the mirror - so much younger than the Jenny we have seen with David. She makes herself up, and she gets older and more glamorous before our eyes. In her make-up and her school uniform, she's half-woman, half- child. We hear the noises drifting up from the kitchen: the radio, the washing-up, occasional muffled conversation. Jenny walks out of the bedroom and slips downstairs. 81    INT. KITCHEN. EVENING                                        81 Jenny's mother and father are doing the washing up and listening to the radio. They have their backs to the door. Jenny enters the room quietly and watches them for a moment
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They do need some looking after, but nothing that will require too much work. Just leave them in your potting shed for a couple of weeks, and they'll look after themselves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, aye. The potting shed. Who does he think I am? Prince Rainier of Monaco?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What if I got married instead of going to college? Jack and Marjorie turn around and stare at this strange apparition wearing too much make-up and a school uniform.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Married?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Married.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It would depend who it was, surely?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Would it? That's interesting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Course it would. I wouldn't want you married off just for the sake of it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thanks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Has somebody asked you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who? Marjorie rolls her eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What did you tell him?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nothing yet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: David?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. A man I just met walking his dog.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: David's asked you to marry him? Bloody hell. Pardon my French.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you have any choice? Or is it too late. She looks at her daughter knowingly. Jack merely looks confused.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course she's got a choice. But it's an interesting one, isn't it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is where you're supposed to say, "But what about Oxford?"
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well. Looked at it one way, you wouldn't really need to go now, would you? He's a man going places. And say what you like, but they know how to take care of their money, don't they? He'll see you're looked after.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (quietly, turning the words over in her mouth) I wouldn't need to go. Would you like to expand on that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know what I mean. Jenny laughs bitterly. She can't believe it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All that Latin! All those essays! What was the point? Why didn't you just send me out prowling round nightclubs? It would have been less trouble. And I might have had more fun.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We don't know about nightclubs. We knew about education. Anyway, it all turned out for the best.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He wouldn't have wanted you if you were thick, would he? Jenny stares at them and walks out. 82   INT. CLASSROOM. DAY                                          82 English. Miss Stubbs is standing at the front   of the class, holding a copy of King Lear, and listening as   various members of the class massacre the text. Some    are messing about by overacting; others read to the best     of their ability, tonelessly and with no understanding   of the words.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Lear himself is being read by Ann, the bespectacled girl from the first scene. She's no King Lear, and she's one of the bad readers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: May not an ass know when the cart draws the horse? Sings whoop jug I love thee.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, when it says `Sings', it means he sings those words. Girl 1 looks at her blankly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Never mind. Lear...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: not Lear. Does Lear walk thus?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (sotto voce, to Jenny, in the seat next to her) No. Jenny starts to giggle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: discernings are lethargied. Ha! Waking? Tis not so. Who is it that can tell me who I am? Jenny's arm shoots up, as if to answer the question.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ooh. Miss. Me. I can. Miss Stubbs looks at Jenny more in sorrow than in anger - Jenny's behaviour now is something new in their relationship. Jenny stares back at her defiantly. Suddenly Miss Stubbs notices something glinting on her hand: an engagement ring.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, Jenny. She is, as she promised she would be, heartbroken.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Take it off. Hattie, who is sitting behind Jenny, notices the ring, too, for the first time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh my God. Is that really what I think it is? I'M GOING TO BE A BRIDESMAID! There is an excited susurration in the classroom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know there's a school rule about jewelry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Half the girls in this room are wearing jewelry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. But none of it is going to ruin their lives.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (coolly) We have a difference of opinion on that. Miss Stubbs stares at her. Jenny can only just steel herself to stare back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let's see who's right. Come with me. Jenny doesn't move.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please don't make me drag you out like a child. Jenny gets to her feet. Teacher and pupil leave the room, while the rest of the class watches.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 83   INT. HEADMISTRESS'S OFFICE. DAY                      83 HEADMISTRESS How far advanced are these ridiculous plans? Have you set a date? Have you decided on a church?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We won't be getting married in a church. David's Jewish. The headmistress stares at her, dumbfounded.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jewish? He's a Jew? You're aware, I take it, that the Jews killed our Lord?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (beginning to feel less intimidated by her surroundings) And you're aware, I suppose, that our Lord was Jewish? The headmistress snorts scornfully
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I suppose he told you that. We're all very sorry about what happened in the War. But there's no excuse for that sort of malicious and untruthful propaganda. Jenny smiles to herself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anyway, I can now see that you are even more in need of responsible advice than I realised. Is it true that you don't intend to sit for your exams? And therefore you won't be applying for University?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, that's right.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you think you're doing?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nobody has been able to explain to me the point of University.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Therefore I don't see the point of the exams, either.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nobody does anything worth doing without a degree.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And nobody does anything worth doing with one, either. No woman, anyway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So what I do isn't worth doing. Or what Miss Stubbs does, or Mrs Wilson, or any of us here. Jenny doesn't say anything. The headmistress takes her silence as an admission of defeat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because none of us would be here without our degrees, you realise that, don't you? And yes, of course studying is hard, and boring, and... Jenny can't contain herself any longer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Boring!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Studying is hard and boring. Teaching is hard and boring. So you're telling me to be bored, and then bored, and then finally bored again, this time for the rest of my life. This whole stupid country is bored. There's no life in it, or colour in it, or fun in it. It's probably just as well that the Russians are going to drop a nuclear bomb on us any day now. So my choice is either to do something hard and boring, OR to marry my... my Jew, and go to Paris and Rome and listen to jazz and read and eat good food in nice restaurants and have fun. It's not enough to educate us any more, Mrs Walters. You've got to tell us why you're doing it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because without formal qualifications... She grinds to a halt. She has never had to answer this question before.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It doesn't have to be teaching, you know. There's the Civil Service. Jenny stands up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't wish to be impertinent, Mrs Walters. But it is an argument worth rehearsing. You never know. Someone else might want to know what the point of it all is, one day. She leaves the office. 84   EXT. SCHOOL. DAY                                            84 Jenny is half-walking, half-running, towards the school gates. She's scared, of course, but exhilarated, too. All that pressure, and all those years of education, suddenly over, unexpectedly, and certainly unceremoniously. She looks neither left nor right, but other girls, younger girls, watch her through the windows as she leaves. Jenny doesn't even look round when she goes through the school gates. 85   INT. KITCHEN. EVENING                                       85 Later. Jenny and Marjorie are sitting at the kitchen table. Jack is standing over them; he hasn't even taken his coat off, or put his briefcase down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How d'you mean, left? Jenny doesn't answer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What about your exams?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not sitting them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are we going to tell people?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (witheringly) Oh, telling people. I'd forgotten that what we tell people is more important than anything.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All that... Marjorie knows what he's going to say, and doesn't want him to.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jack!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. No need for Jack. She should hear it. All that money! Do you know how much it's cost me for you to go through school and take no exams?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sure David will pay you back. Send him a bill. As you said, he wouldn't have wanted me if I was dim, so he should fork out. Just tell me why there's a point in sitting my exams, and there's no point in me going to University. Jack gapes at her. He's floundering.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know what your trouble is, don't you? You're too clever by half.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In which case I should have left school years ago, shouldn't I? Ask them for the money back. If I'm too clever by half, you overpaid by a third. 86   INT. DANNY'S FLAT. NIGHT                                     86 Danny, Helen, David and Jenny are in Danny's flat; we have just missed The Announcement - there is champagne already open. Danny glances quickly and discreetly at David, who catches his eye.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's...Gosh. That's fantastic news.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Danny isn't so pleased.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (cool) Congratulations. There is much chinking of glasses.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I thought you'd see sense about university. Jenny smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You'll stay pretty now. Laughter from David and Jenny.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Am I still allowed to read?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: English? Books? More laughter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You won't be laughing when she goes all speccy and spotty, David. Helen is bemused by their mirth. Danny watches   David thoughtfully. 87   EXT. DANNY'S. NIGHT                                            87 David and Jenny come out of Danny's flat and approach David's car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Danny didn't seem very pleased about our engagement.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I thought that, too! I was wondering whether he might be a bit jealous.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (trying not to be pleased) Jealous?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You may have noticed that Helen's not really Oxford material. I'm going to keep him out of your way. They both smile. David opens the door for Jenny and she gets into the car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: an eye on Jenny - in Marjorie's mind at least, this is a rehearsal for something.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: knitted tea-cosy and puts it on her head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (oblivious) No. On the tea-pot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: tries to think of somewhere Jenny might find interesting.) We could walk to the British Museum! Jenny gives her a look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: it stew. She leaves the room.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: The office is dark, wood-panelled, foreboding, apparently designed to put all visitors ill-at-ease. The headmistress would probably choose to be wood-panelled if she could. She's tweedy, bespectacled, severe. There is a knock at the door. She doesn't look up from her paperwork.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: David and Jenny aren't on it, though. They are letting themselves into the room. Jenny stares at the featureless
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A suite!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: There are a lot of things I didn't tell you. I was dreaming.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's the thing about our lives, isn't it? It's so easy to fall asleep, when there's nothing to keep you awake. Beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you getting on with the work all right on your own?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Jenny thinks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. No, I'm not. 114   EXT. STREET MISS STUBBS FLAT. DUSK.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She finds the house, walks down the path, rings on a bell. Miss Stubbs comes to the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jenny! It's a warm greeting. She ushers her inside. 115   INT. MISS STUBBS' FLAT. DUSK.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's a proper Bohemian flat, up in the eaves. There are books and papers and paintings covering every available surface. Jenny looks around. Finally, for the first time, we see her in somewhere she can feel at home.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is lovely. Miss Stubbs makes a face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But it is. Really. I'd love to live somewhere like this. Miss Stubbs laughs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, it's not hard. Go to Oxford and become a teacher and this is what you end up with.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But all these books and pictures....
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Penguin paperbacks. Posters and postcards.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, but...That's all you need, isn't it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Just a place to...I'm sorry I said those silly things. I didn't understand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let's forget all about it. A poster catches Jenny's eye.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Burne-Jones. Miss Stubbs laughs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You make it sound as though it's an original. Do you like him? Jenny pauses.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. I do. Still.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Still? Gosh, you sound very old and wise.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I feel old. But really not very wise. Miss Stubbs, I'm....I need your help.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was so hoping that's what you were going to say. 116   EXT. STREET IN OXFORD. DAY                                 116 Eighteen months later. Swelling orchestral music. Close on Jenny cycling, absorbed, happy, the cello strapped to her precariously. The camera pulls back to show her cycling through the streets of Oxford. She's done it. We follow her for a little while. She dismounts outside a church and leans the bike against a wall. Just as she's about to leave it, she sees something and freezes. We follow her gaze: it's the red Bristol, parked a little way down the road just in front of her. She scans the street to see if she can find David. She can - he's coming round a corner, a littler further down the street, unwrapping a packet of cigarettes. Jenny moves into his eye-line. He sees her, stops, then walks towards her.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (to Jack)

dialogue.raw_text: I don't really understand what difference it makes. When I found out that...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Helen! Not now. Helen shrugs.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (bitterly) It's a funny world you people live in. You both watched me... carrying on with a married man, but you don't think it's worth saying anything.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ah, well if you want that sort of conversation...You watched David and I help ourselves to a map, and you didn't say much, either. He holds Jenny's gaze. She looks away.
dialogue.name: dialogue
